channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Though Adversaries on the Surface, U.S. and Hezbollah Share a Goal
item.description: In practice, Hezbollah and the United States are already working — separately — on a common goal: to stop the extremist Islamic State from moving into Lebanon.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Pakistani Military Names New Spy Agency Chief
item.description: The new head of the powerful Inter-Services Intelligence agency, Lt. Gen. Rizwan Akhtar, may offer American officials hope of a better relationship.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Despite Airstrikes, ISIS Appears to Hold Its Ground in Iraq
item.description: After six weeks of Western air support, Iraqi forces have scarcely budged Islamic State fighters from their hold on more than a quarter of the country.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A photo posted on a militant website last week shows fighters from the Islamic State group in front of a police station in Nineveh province, Iraq.

item.title: Over 130,000 Flee Syria for Turkey in Wake of ISIS Raids
item.description: Turkey’s deputy prime minister said the Islamic State’s advance was causing a crisis “worse than a natural disaster” in his country.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Schools Under Fire for Too Much Pomp in Military Training
item.description: College administrators in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui have come under criticism for conducting head-of-state-style reviews of students participating in military-style training.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rural Library Chain Closes, Citing ‘Tremendous Pressure’
item.description: A nongovernmental organization that had run a rural library project with as many as 22 libraries across China has announced it is closing down, pointing to “tremendous pressure” from the local authorities.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Liren board members (its founder, Li Yingqiang, is second from right) staged an online protest after announcing its dissolution. The signs read: “Burned but not destroyed.”

item.title: Explosions Kill at Least 2 in Restive Region of China
item.description: The blasts in Xinjiang occurred on the same day that 17 officials were punished for failing to prevent attacks in July that left almost 100 dead.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Tibetan Student Burns Himself to Death in Protest
item.description: The 22-year-old man was protesting Chinese rule. It was the first self-immolation in five months, a human rights organization said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Hong Kong Students Lead Democracy Fight With Class Boycott
item.description: The strikers, who said they would skip class all week, are at the vanguard of a series of protests against limits set by China for selection of the city’s leader.
item.category: Chinese University of Hong Kong, The
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Students demonstrated at the Chinese University of Hong Kong on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Glen Peters on China and Climate Change
item.description: A scientist with the Global Carbon Project argues that China holds the key to promoting renewable energy and limiting global warming.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Smoke rising from chimneys and cooling towers of a thermal power plant in Liaoning Province, China.

item.title: Promises of Greater Home Rule for Scots Turn Contentious
item.description: After voters rejected independence from the United Kingdom, politicians quickly began bickering over how to transfer more powers to Scotland.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: For Airbnb and Uber, an Uneven Response by Regulators
item.description: For technology start-ups like Airbnb and Uber, efforts to gain a stronger foothold in European countries have been complicated by varying regulations from different governments.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER and MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Patricia de Melo Moreira for The New York Times
item.media:description: A law in Portugal will force renters like André Penin to register their apartments with local municipalities.

item.title: Family’s Video Appeals to Iran for Release of American
item.description: A video featuring the terminally ill father of Amir Hekmati, who has been incarcerated for three years, was released near the opening of the United Nations General Assembly.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Amir Hekmati, shown in an undated photo, has been incarcerated for three years.

item.title: Russians Protest Putin’s Stance on Ukraine
item.description: Thousands of Russians marched through Moscow on Sunday in an antigovernment demonstration criticizing President Vladimir V. Putin for what they saw as his warmongering in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A man wore a Ukrainian flag around his shoulders during an antiwar rally in Moscow that drew thousands on Sunday.

item.title: Growing Imbalance Between Germany and France Strains Their Relationship
item.description: French leaders are facing the pressure of their own weakened economy and the continuing austerity push of the German chancellor, Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France is arriving in Berlin on Monday for talks.

item.title: Mexico Makes Route Tougher for Migrants
item.description: Mexico has taken unusual steps to stem the flow of migrants traveling from Central America to the United States, sweeping trains, setting up checkpoints and raiding hotels and flophouses.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Linz Am Rhein Journal: In the Rhine Valley, Clamoring for Relief From Ramped-Up Rail
item.description: A vital stretch along Europe’s most important north-south rail route is being overrun with train traffic, spoiling the quality of life for residents in a region famous for its natural beauty.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Benjamin Kilb for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ewald A. Hoppen, who leads a group opposing railway noise, stands in front of a passing freight train.

item.title: Soldiers’ Graves Bear Witness to Russia’s Role in Ukraine
item.description: Even as the Kremlin tries to deny its involvement and families are pressured to keep quiet, the deaths of soldiers sent to fight in Ukraine are impossible to ignore.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ALEXANDRA ODYNOVA
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The grave of Sgt. Vladislav A. Barakov, a soldier sent to fight in Ukraine, states the day he died, Aug. 24, but not where or how.

item.title: With One Battle Over in Scotland, Another Begins
item.description: In the town near Gleneagles, where the Ryder Cup will begin Friday, people have swapped the political passions of last week for the breezier enthusiasms of preparing for one of golf’s greatest events.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparations for the Ryder Cup in Scotland are underway as Auchterarder residents try to put secession politics aside.

item.title: After Rancor, Afghans Agree to Share Power
item.description: After eight months of enmity over the protracted presidential election, Ashraf Ghani and Abdullah Abdullah will have to confront the challenges of jointly governing their country.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, center left, and Ashraf Ghani embraced during a brief ceremony on Sunday during which the two men signed a power-sharing agreement.

item.title: Yemen Rebels Gain Concessions From Government After Assault on Capital
item.description: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi announced that the rebels, known as the Houthis, had agreed to an immediate cease-fire and the formation of a new government, a process in which they were expected to hold sway.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Spurred by ISIS Violence, Nations Mull How to Press for Justice in Conflicts
item.description: Western governments set about devising a strategy for speeding prosecution of those responsible for grave crimes in the conflict in Syria and Iraq.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: ISIS Forays Send Waves of Refugees Into Turkey
item.description: The refugee crisis near the Syrian border town of Ayn al-Arab could be one of the greatest refugee flows since the civil war in Syria began, said a United Nations official.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: A Turkish soldier at the border in Suruc, Turkey, threw a pack of water Sunday to Syrian refugees fleeing Islamic State militants.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bottom-Up Climate Fix
item.description: International treaties haven’t worked. Enabling local and corporate leaders could.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL C. ESTY

item.title: Obama to Lead U.N. Effort to Halt Movement of Terror Recruits
item.description: An unusual meeting of the United Nations Security Council is poised to adopt a resolution that would compel all countries to adopt laws to prosecute those who travel abroad to join terrorist organizations and those who help them.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and SOMINI SENGUPTA
